Posts.Content: Feb 1, 2011 07:42AM cms77 wrote: Hi Tori, I'm starting rads this month too.  I call today to set up the prep session.  Three weeks ago I had a BMX with TE's.  Had neoadjuvant chemo.  Path report shows chemo did it's job on me; no tumor left and only 2 nodes had microscopic cancer left.  It's all good news. Now onto rads. I agree, it's good to have all us share out experiences and learn from each other. Looking forward to hearing from others starting rads this month and those that have already been through it.  Christine
Posts.Title: February 2011 Rads ToriGirl Elisimo

Posts.Content: Jan 20, 2011 11:46AM cms77 wrote: Hi, just a little update.  Saw PS and he's very happy with the nipple reconstruction (2 nipples made from one) and said my skin and everything looks great  The dressings came off the nipples so I am able to shower!  I was a little nervous at first, but after I got in, nothing hurt. Also got 2 of my 4 drains removed, so I feel like progress is being made. Only have 100cc in each TE, so the plan is to start expanding me next week.  I seem to be rambling, but I'm very pleased with my outcome so far. Pain is almost gone, really just a little sore from time to time, so I've been using Mortrin for the past 2 days. On antibiotics 4x day.  Been having issues with nausea, so have been taking Compazine leftover from chemo which really helps and  Ativan for sleeping at night. Thinking of Terri, CJ, and Vikki today.  I know you will all do wonderful and heal quickly. Continued healing to the rest! {{{hugs}}} Christine
Posts.Title: January 2011 Mastectomy ibcmets SuebeeBC

Posts.Content: Dec 19, 2010 12:29PM cms77 wrote: Welcome, Elizabeth!  Sorry to hear all you've been through so far.  Even for me this process seems to just drag on and on.  But it is a process and one we must go through in order to become cancer free and minimize our risk (to hopefully zero!!) for the cancer ever coming back.  Good luck with your surgery!  Christine
Posts.Title: January 2011 Mastectomy ibcmets SuebeeBC

Posts.Content: Dec 23, 2010 02:51PM cms77 wrote: Hi ladies, I saw my PS yesterday.  I am clear now as to how he can fully expand the TEs on the table.  Since I'm having skin sparing BMX and have extra breast skin due to sagging breasts (never thought that would be a plus), it's kinda like having a breast lift and the TEs are going to be used as place holders while I wait to have my implants.  Ideally, permanent implants would be put in immediately, but since I'm having radiation after surgery, that is not advisable.  So, the TEs will not be used to stretch the muscles of the chest since they can use my breast skin.  I was told that one of my PS's patients had the same type of surgery recently and she had very little pain.  I am so relieved I finally understand how my surgery is planned to be performed. And hoping for very little pain as well, but everyone is different. Christine
Posts.Title: January 2011 Mastectomy ibcmets SuebeeBC

Posts.Content: Jan 16, 2011 10:37PM cms77 wrote: Will be thinking of the girls going for surgery this week: Renee, Claire, Jorja, Terri, Vikki, and CJ.  You can do this! Christine
Posts.Title: January 2011 Mastectomy ibcmets SuebeeBC

Posts.Content: Jan 21, 2011 08:38AM cms77 wrote: Hi Gutsy, My bruising isn't too bad, and I would say the type of bruising you describe is probably normal. The chemo I had before surgery really did it's job on me. My pathology came back showing no tumor at all in my right breast so the chemo wiped that out completely, and 4 of the 18 lymph nodes showed signs of cancer.  Prior to chemo, it was thought that a dozen or more nodes had cancer.  This is all good news for me going forward with the rest of my life.  I am still having radiation since the tumor was resting on the wall of my chest, and just to make sure all cancer cells have been eliminated, radiation is highly suggested.  Then after radiation, I too will have hormon therapy. MDG:  Welcome and know that even though chemo sucks, you will survive it.  I understand how scared you must be. I was very stressed about it as well and all the decisions you have to make. It's a long processes getting better.  Christine

Posts.Content: Dec 16, 2010 12:07PM cms77 wrote: Thanks Renee, Laurie, and Terri! I want the least amount of pain as well!  I am having radiation after surgery, so that may be part of the reason my PS said he would fill me fully on the table since I've read and heard that once the muscle is radiated, it won't stretch anymore.  But I won't start rads until 4 to 5 weeks post surgery. I can't wait to see PS next week to find out more about his reasoning because this is bugging me. Christine

Posts.Content: Jan 8, 2011 09:25AM cms77 wrote: I've been away this week and see I've missed a lot of posts.  Laurie and Gutsy, I'm glad you are recovering well from surgery.  Next Wednesday the 12th I'm scheduled.  My doctor's office called yesterday to say my white blood cell count is low, rechecking on Monday.  Will they still do surgery if my count is still low?  I didn't think to ask that question.  I really would rather not have to postpone.  I want to get the surgery over with even though I'm so nervous about it. Christine

Posts.Content: Jan 18, 2011 12:51PM cms77 wrote: Renee - thinking of you today. Cindy - I know how scary it must be for you, waiting for your CT and bone scans. The waiting is so hard. I pray the cancer is localized to the lymph nodes. Do you know how many were positive?  Christine

Posts.Content: Dec 8, 2010 11:59AM cms77 wrote: Hi Terri, Thank you for starting this thread. I am scheduled for a bilateral on January 12th.  I had 8 rounds of chemo - 4 A/C and 4 Taxol, completed the last Taxol two days ago.  So happy that part is over.  I will be having TE put in at the time of the surgery, prior to radiation.  My tumor is in the right breast and has responded well to chemo, it has shrunk.  BS is optimistic that they can do skin sparing and nipple sparing on at least the left breast if not both.  Have to have lymph nodes removed from right arm because cancer was found in at least one node during the biopsy the confirmed the breast cancer.  I am looking forward to checking in and see how everyone is doing throughout our recovery. Christine
Posts.Title: January 2011 Mastectomy ibcmets SuebeeBC

Posts.Content: Dec 31, 2010 04:07PM cms77 wrote: Gutsy - I agree, it may be best to stay with your mom.  I'm contemplating staying with my brother and his family. My husband doesn't get it either, but I think I may miss my boys too much.  We'll see. Happy New Year! Christine
Posts.Title: January 2011 Mastectomy ibcmets SuebeeBC

Posts.Content: Jan 16, 2011 07:01PM cms77 wrote: Hi Everyone, I came home Saturday after 3 nights in the hospital.  Had skin sparing, nipple sparring BMX with tissue expanders and full lymph node dissection in my right arm on Jan 12th.  Was in a lot of pain immediately after surgery and the first two days, but doing much better managing the pain today.  Have 4 drains, 2 on each side.  My husband is a great help with these because no way can I reach them to strip them.  Had home health care nurse in today and she said I was doing great, the incisions and drains all look great too.  I'm sleeping in bed propped up on pillows; decided my reclining couch is not as comfortable as I thought.  Hate sleeping on my back but have no choice.  Very tired and not doing much, taking naps whenever I feel like it. Have never watched so much tv in my life  Surgeons were both very happy with the surgery, said I did great, and are very happy with the way my skin and incisions look.  Will be seeing PS sometime this coming week, hoping to get rid of at least two of these drains. Will get another fill in my TE's; only have about 100 cc in there now. Each day is better than the last. My advice is to take things one day at a time and to roll with whatever comes your way because you can deal with it and things will get better.  This is doable. Christine
Posts.Title: January 2011 Mastectomy ibcmets SuebeeBC

Posts.Content: Dec 13, 2010 11:50AM cms77 wrote: Cindy, I too am having surgery anxiety, and I feel like I burden friends and family when I want to vent about it.  I have been reading many posts on this site and it helps me to not feel all alone in this journey. I am nervous about the pain and discomfort I will have from the bi-lateral with TE placed immediately, and lymph node disection. Some posters seem to have pain many weeks after surgery with their TEs. My PS said he thinks he can get me expanded fully on the table.  That sounds painful to me.  I'm a shooting for a C cup since that's what I am now. I don't even know how many cc's that is.  I see my PS next week, so I have lots more questions for him.  Has anyone heard of being expanded on the table immediately, and fully expanded? Christine
Posts.Title: January 2011 Mastectomy ibcmets SuebeeBC

Posts.Content: Dec 22, 2010 12:15PM cms77 wrote: I am back on the treadmill, starting to work on my core again, and a little weight training.  I had terrible pain with the Taxol/Nuelasta shot and am finally feeling up to working out again.  I worked out more when I was on A/C than I did on Taxol, which is opposite what I expected. 3 weeks to go before surgery...  Christine

Posts.Content: Jan 27, 2011 12:00PM cms77 wrote: Last 2 drains and stitches came out yesterday, feels great. Going in for my first fill next Tuesday. Didn't want to get a fill yesterday, getting the drains and stitches out were enough for one day. I haven't told anyone, but I've been doing my eliptical for about a week now, for just 20 minutes or so but it's enough for now. Terri, I cannot tolerate pain meds very well either. Took a vicodin yesterday because I was getting the drains out and almost threw up in the car on the way back home. I came home and slept most of the afternoon. And I took a compazine to help with the nausea. Worked for me. I'm tired all the time too. Not sleeping well all of a sudden. Christine
Posts.Title: January 2011 Mastectomy ibcmets SuebeeBC

Posts.Content: Jan 29, 2011 10:32AM cms77 wrote: Terri, I feel so bad for you going through all that hassle with the pain medicine.  But you are much better now so that's great!  Things do get better, don't they?  I'm getting used to my TE's.  Finally slept better last night after 3 nights of not sleeping.  Slept on both sides of my body.  Seems silly that I'm so happy to be do that.  But, it's the little things we get thrilled about, isn't it?   Does anyone know or have heard if it's ok to sleep on the side that had lymph node dissection?  I asked a nurse and she said she didn't see why not.  I'm so worried about developing lymphadema I think of it constantly.  I see my surgeon this week so I'll ask her, but just wondered if anyone here knows.  I'll check the lymphadema board as well.  Christine
